title: 110_hr765
content: There is no information provided in the prev_chunk to assist with summarizing the curr_chunk. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new credits for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles and qualified alternative fuel motor vehicles. The new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle credit is determined under subsection (e) and the new qualified alternative fuel motor vehicle credit is determined under subsection (f). The credit amount for the new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle is based on the vehicle placed in service during the taxable year. The credit amount for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles and qualified alternative fuel motor vehicles is determined based on a table for the taxable year. The credit amount for vehicles with city fuel economy percentages ranging from 125% to over 225% compared to a comparable vehicle varies from $1,500 to $3,500. The city fuel economy of a new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle must be determined on an E-85 ethanol gallon equivalent basis, while the comparable vehicle's fuel economy is determined on a gasoline gallon equivalent basis. The term 'new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle' refers to a vehicle capable of operating on alternative fuel, gasoline, or any blend, certified to achieve a city fuel economy using E-85 ethanol of at least 125. The text discusses the extension of the termination date for a new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle credit under section 30B of the Code. It also includes amendments related to vehicles included in the numeric limitation and conforming amendments. The text discusses amendments to section 30B of the Code, including changes to subsections (i)(5), (i)(6), and (k). These changes involve redesignating subsections and specifying exceptions for new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles. The amendments to section 30B of the Code involve changes to subsections (b) and (h), with effective date after December 31, 2006.
